modulesynopsis.name: mod_brotli
modulesynopsis.description: Compress content via Brotli before it is delivered to the client

summary.p: The mod_brotli module provides the BROTLI_COMPRESS output filter that allows output from your server to be compressed using the brotli compression format before being sent to the client over the network.

section.title: Sample Configurations

note.title: Compression and TLS
note.p: Some web applications are vulnerable to an information disclosure attack when a TLS connection carries compressed data. For more information, review the details of the "BREACH" family of attacks.

section.p: This is a simple configuration that compresses common text-based content types.

example.title: Compress only a few types
example.highlight: AddOutputFilterByType BROTLI_COMPRESS text/html text/plain text/xml text/css text/javascript application/javascript

note.title: Compression and TLS

section.p: Compression is implemented by the BROTLI_COMPRESS filter. The following directive will enable compression for documents in the container where it is placed:

If you want to restrict the compression to particular MIME types in general, you may use the AddOutputFilterByType directive. Here is an example of enabling compression only for the html files of the Apache documentation:
section.note: Note The BROTLI_COMPRESS filter is always inserted after RESOURCE filters like PHP or SSI. It never touches internal subrequests.
Note There is an environment variable no-brotli, set via SetEnv, which will disable brotli compression for a particular request, even if it is supported by the client.

section.title: Dealing with proxy servers
section.p: The mod_brotli module sends a Vary: Accept-Encoding HTTP response header to alert proxies that a cached response should be sent only to clients that send the appropriate Accept-Encoding request header. This prevents compressed content from being sent to a client that will not understand it.

If you use some special exclusions dependent on, for example, the User-Agent header, you must manually configure an addition to the Vary header to alert proxies of the additional restrictions. If your decision about compression depends on other information than request headers (e.g. HTTP version), you have to set the Vary header to the value *. This prevents compliant proxies from caching entirely.

section.title: Serving pre-compressed content
section.p: Since mod_brotli re-compresses content each time a request is made, some performance benefit can be derived by pre-compressing the content and telling mod_brotli to serve them without re-compressing them. This may be accomplished using a configuration like the following:
section.highlight:
<IfModule mod_headers.c> # Serve brotli compressed CSS files if they exist # and the client accepts brotli. RewriteCond "%{HTTP:Accept-encoding}" "brotli" RewriteCond "%{REQUEST_FILENAME}\.br" "-s" RewriteRule "^(.*)\.css" "$1\.css\.br" [QSA]
# Serve brotli compressed JS files if they exist # and the client accepts brotli. RewriteCond "%{HTTP:Accept-encoding}" "brotli" RewriteCond "%{REQUEST_FILENAME}\.br" "-s" RewriteRule "^(.*)\.js" "$1\.js\.br" [QSA]
# Serve correct content types, and prevent mod_brotli double brotli. RewriteRule "\.css\.gz$" "-" [T=text/css,E=no-brotli:1] RewriteRule "\.js\.gz$" "-" [T=text/javascript,E=no-brotli:1]
<FilesMatch "(\.js\.gz|\.css\.gz)$"> # Serve correct encoding type. Header append Content-Encoding brotli
# Force proxies to cache brotli & # non-brotli css/js files separately. Header append Vary Accept-Encoding </FilesMatch> </IfModule>

directivesynopsis.name: BrotliFilterNote
directivesynopsis.description: Places the compression ratio in a note for logging

usage.p: The BrotliFilterNote directive specifies that a note about compression ratios should be attached to the request. The name of the note is the value specified for the directive. You can use that note for statistical purposes by adding the value to your access log.

example.title: Example
example.highlight:
BrotliFilterNote ratio
LogFormat '"%r" %b (%{ratio}n) "%{User-agent}i"' brotli CustomLog "logs/brotli_log" brotli

usage.p: If you want to extract more accurate values from your logs, you can use the type argument to specify the type of data left as a note for logging. type can be one of:

dl.dd: Store the byte count of the filter's input stream in the note.
Store the byte count of the filter's output stream in the note.
Store the compression ratio (output/input * 100) in the note. This is the default, if the type argument is omitted.

usage.p: Thus you may log it this way:

example.title: Accurate Logging
example.highlight:
BrotliFilterNote Input instream BrotliFilterNote Output outstream BrotliFilterNote Ratio ratio
LogFormat '"%r" %{outstream}n/%{instream}n (%{ratio}n%%)' brotli CustomLog "logs/brotli_log" brotli

usage.p: The BrotliCompressionQuality directive specifies the compression quality (a value between 0 and 11). Higher quality values result in better, but also slower compression.
The BrotliCompressionWindow directive specifies the brotli sliding compression window size (a value between 10 and 24). Larger window sizes can improve compression quality, but require more memory.
The BrotliCompressionMaxInputBlock directive specifies the maximum input block size between 16 and 24, with the caveat that larger block sizes require more memory.

directivesynopsis.name: BrotliAlterETag
directivesynopsis.description: How the outgoing ETag header should be modified during compression

usage.p: The BrotliAlterETag directive specifies how the ETag hader should be altered when a response is compressed.

dd.p: Append the compression method onto the end of the ETag, causing compressed and uncompressed representations to have unique ETags. In another dynamic compression module, mod_deflate, this has been the default since 2.4.0. This setting prevents serving "HTTP Not Modified" (304) responses to conditional requests for compressed content.

Don't change the ETag on a compressed response. In another dynamic compression module, mod_deflate, this has been the default prior to 2.4.0. This setting does not satisfy the HTTP/1.1 property that all representations of the same resource have unique ETags.
Remove the ETag header from compressed responses. This prevents some conditional requests from being possible, but avoids the shortcomings of the preceding options.
